results.headline: Burning Rubber One More Time
results.summary_short: This example of presummer pop diversion will be best appreciated by future audiences flabbergasted by its unabashed revelry in fossil-fuel consumption.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast & Furious

results.headline: Big-Band Blues
results.summary_short: “Bart Got a Room” is a teenage comedy with an old-fogy scent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bart Got a Room (Movie)

results.headline: A Hapless Romantic, Smitten on the Steppe
results.summary_short: “Tulpan” might be described as an epic landscape film or a sweetly comic coming-of-age story. But the setting gives the movie a science fiction mood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tulpan

results.headline: A Documentary Gives ‘Going to the Mat’ New Meaning
results.summary_short: “Enlighten Up!” explores its subject with a light touch and welcome sense of humor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enlighten Up!

results.headline: Tentatively Approaching the Possibilities of Love
results.summary_short: The matchmaking games in Emmanuel Mouret’s romantic comedy “Shall We Kiss?” may backfire, but nobody is seriously hurt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shall We Kiss?

results.headline: Criminal Takes Policeman on Big-City Scavenger Hunt
results.summary_short: Renny Harlin’s “12 Rounds” satisfies, on the most primitive level, the expectations for a second-rate action flick.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12 Rounds

results.headline: Life Lessons Learned in Bucolic Classrooms
results.summary_short: The film’s portrayal of farm life as a rugged pastorale lends “The Country Teacher” a foundation of visceral truth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Country Teacher

results.headline: For a Buoyant Cabby, a Ride to Remember
results.summary_short: The story told in “Goodbye Solo,” Ramin Bahrani’s wonderful third feature, is moving and mysterious.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye Solo

results.headline: Crash Course in Racism at Quiet Campus
results.summary_short: This movie adaptation of Rebecca Gilman’s play is a methodical, not to say mechanical and plodding, exploration of identity politics and language.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spinning Into Butter

results.headline: Probing Class Consciousness
results.summary_short: “The Education of Charlie Banks” is a prickly examination of the sturdiness of class boundaries and the illusion of inclusion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Education of Charlie Banks

results.headline: Where the Action Was
results.summary_short: “American Swing” interweaves reminiscences of onetime patrons of the swingers’ clup Plato’s Retreat with grainy, scenes of party life inside the club.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Swing

results.headline: Warring Dynasties and Ancient Grudges
results.summary_short: “The Perfect Sleep” fuses Shakespearean tragedy and noir iconography into a strange, lovely, leaden ball of confusion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Sleep

results.headline: For the Love of Art
results.summary_short: “Guest of Cindy Sherman” is at once a fascinating behind-the-scenes glimpse, bittersweet autobiography and witty trip down art-world memory lane.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guest of Cindy Sherman

results.headline: 3-D Fun With a Beefed-Up Bride and a Dumb Blob Named B.O.B.
results.summary_short: “Monsters vs. Aliens” cheerfully converts two major sources of cinematic terror into wacky, goofy, familiar figures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monsters vs. Aliens

results.headline: A Family Plot
results.summary_short: “The Haunting in Connecticut” gives you the creeps, the giggles and the groans in almost equal measure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Haunting in Connecticut

results.headline: Long-Time Traveler
results.summary_short: Whether you rejoice in Arthur Blessit’s peregrinations or take him for a genuine (if basically harmless) quack, “The Cross” is not likely to inspire.
results.display_title: The Cross: The Arthur Blessitt Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cross: The Arthur Blessitt Story

results.headline: Effervescent Espionage With Two Irresistible Forces
results.summary_short: However you describe it, “Duplicity” is superior entertainment, the most elegantly pleasurable movie of its kind to come around in a very long time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Duplicity

results.headline: 20-something Sloth and Larceny
results.summary_short: “Skills Like This” gazes indulgently on 20-something aimlessness and the comfort of assigned roles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skills Like This

results.headline: Late-Capitalist Malaise in New York
results.summary_short: “The New Twenty” manufactures a mess of conflicts and comeuppances for its characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The New Twenty

results.headline: Strangers Who Sweat Together
results.summary_short: Three women, three generations, one problem: “Steam,” a movie so cheesy and so poorly acted that it should never have seen the light of day.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Steam
